[[William Hely]] (1951–53) }} '''Western Area Command''' was one of several [[RAAF area commands|geographically based commands]] raised by the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) during World War II. It was formed in January 1941, and controlled RAAF units located in [[Western Australia]]. Headquartered at [[Perth]], Western Area Command was primarily responsible for [[Anti-aircraft warfare|air defence]], [[aerial reconnaissance]] and protection of the [[sea lane]]s within its boundaries. Its aircraft conducted anti-submarine operations throughout the war, and attacked targets in the [[Dutch East Indies]] during the [[Borneo campaign (1945)|Borneo campaign]] in 1945. Western Area Command continued to operate following the end of the war, before its responsibilities were subsumed in 1954 by the RAAF's new functional command-and-control system; the headquarters was disbanded two years later. ==History== ===World War II=== [[File:An010702DeLaRue1941.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.3|Air Commodore De La Rue (in braided cap), inaugural AOC Western Area, inspecting pilot trainees, c. 1941|alt=Two columns of men, some in military uniforms with peaked caps, some in civilian clothes, walking between two rows of troops with forage caps standing to attention with rifles and fixed bayonets, and further rows of troops behind them]] Prior to World War II, the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] was small enough for all its elements to be directly controlled by RAAF Headquarters in [[Melbourne]]. After war broke out in September 1939, the Air Force began to decentralise its command structure, commensurate with expected increases in manpower and units.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 111–112{{cite magazine |title = Organising for war: The RAAF air campaigns in the Pacific | magazine = Pathfinder |issue= 121| date = October 2009| url = http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/403/121-Organising-for-War-The-RAAF-Air-Campaigns-in-the-Pacific.aspx|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=18 June 2016}} Between March 1940 and May 1941, the RAAF divided Australia and New Guinea into four [[RAAF area commands|geographically based command-and-control zones]]: [[Central Area Command (RAAF)|Central Area]], [[Southern Area Command (RAAF)|Southern Area]], Western Area, and [[Northern Area Command (RAAF)|Northern Area]].Gillison, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 91–92] The roles of these area commands were [[Anti-aircraft warfare|air defence]], protection of adjacent [[sea lane]]s, and [[aerial reconnaissance]]. Each was led by an [[Air Officer Commanding]] (AOC) responsible for the administration and operations of all air bases and units within his boundary. Western Area Command, headquartered in [[Perth]], was formed on 9 January 1941 to control all RAAF units in [[Western Australia]].Gillison, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 92] These included [[No. 14 Squadron RAAF|No. 14 (General Reconnaissance) Squadron]], [[No. 25 Squadron RAAF|No. 25 (General Purpose) Squadron]] and No. 5 Initial Training School at [[RAAF Base Pearce|RAAF Station Pearce]]; [[No. 9 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF|No. 9 Elementary Flying Training School]] at [[RAAF Station Cunderdin|Cunderdin]]; and the soon-to-be-raised [[No. 4 Service Flying Training School RAAF|No. 4 Service Flying Training School]] at [[Geraldton Airport|Geraldton]].Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 1 RAAF Headquarters had maintained control of Western Australian units pending the area's formation.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', pp. 28–29 Western Area's inaugural AOC was Group Captain (acting Air Commodore) [[Hippolyte De La Rue|Hippolyte "Kanga" De La Rue]].Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', p. 294 His senior air staff officer was Group Captain [[Alan Charlesworth]]. Headquarters staff numbered forty-one, including fifteen officers.Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', pp. 1–2 No. 14 Squadron, operating [[Lockheed Hudson]]s, and No. 25 Squadron, flying [[CAC Wirraway]]s, were responsible for convoy escort and anti-submarine patrol.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', p. 43{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/Units/25sqn.aspx |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103152136/http://www.airforce.gov.au/units/25sqn.aspx |title=No. 25 (City of Perth) Squadron|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=22 July 2016 |archivedate=3 January 2012}} Shortly after taking command, De La Rue lobbied RAAF Headquarters for a force of long-range [[Consolidated PBY Catalina|Catalina flying boats]] to augment No. 14 Squadron's Hudsons, but none were made available.Wilson, ''The Eagle and the Albatross'', pp. 72–73 [[File:RAAFAreaCommands1942.png|thumb|upright=1.38|alt=Map of Australia showing state borders, with RAAF area command boundaries superimposed|RAAF area commands, November 1942. Other than North-Western Area's boundaries excluding Indonesia after World War II, the boundaries were essentially the same when the area system was superseded in 1953–54.]] By mid-1941, RAAF Headquarters had determined to form training units in the southern and eastern states into semi-geographical, semi-functional groups separate to the area commands. This led to the establishment in August of No. 1 (Training) Group in Melbourne, covering Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia, and No. 2 (Training) Group in Sydney, covering New South Wales and Queensland; at the same time, Central Area was dissolved and its responsibilities divided between Southern and Northern Areas, and No. 2 (Training) Group.Gillison, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 112]Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', pp. xx, 38 Western Area, uniquely among the area commands, retained responsibility for training, as well as operations and maintenance, within its boundaries. In November 1941, all available aircraft from Nos. 14 and 25 Squadrons, as well as eight [[Avro Anson]]s from No. 4 Service Flying Training School, took part in the search for [[HMAS Sydney (D48)|HMAS ''Sydney'']] after it was [[Battle between HMAS Sydney and German auxiliary cruiser Kormoran|sunk by the German raider ''Kormoran'']]; a Hudson and an Anson each located lifeboats bearing [[German auxiliary cruiser Kormoran|''Kormoran'''s]] crew.Gillison, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070478--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 134]RAAF Historical Section, ''Training Units'', pp. 105–106 Following the outbreak of the [[Pacific War]], Northern Area was split in January 1942 into [[North-Western Area Command (RAAF)|North-Western]] and [[North-Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|North-Eastern Areas]], to counter separate Japanese threats to Northern Australia and New Guinea, respectively.Gillison, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070486--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 311] In May, a new area command, [[Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|Eastern Area]], was raised to control units within New South Wales and southern Queensland.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', pp. xxi, 134–135 The same month, the Air Board proposed raising No. 3 (Training) Group and No. 8 (Maintenance) Group to control training and maintenance units in Western Australia but, though approved by the Federal government, this did not take place.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', pp. 134–135 As of 31 May 1942, Western Area headquarters staff numbered 247, including seventy-two officers.Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 89 [[No. 35 Squadron RAAF|No. 35 (Transport) Squadron]], operating [[de Havilland Fox Moth]] and [[De Havilland Dragon|DH.84 Dragon]] aircraft, was raised under Western Area's control at Pearce on 4 March 1942.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070516--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 481]Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 36 [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|No. 77 Squadron]], equipped with [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk variants|P-40 Kittyhawks]], was formed at Pearce on 16 March; it was at this time the only fighter squadron available to defend Perth and [[Fremantle]], and De La Rue worked assiduously to prepare it for operations.Odgers, ''Mr Double Seven'', p. 19 No. 6 Fighter Sector Headquarters, Perth, became operational on 2 May.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', p. 299Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 68 As of 20 April, operational authority over all RAAF combat infrastructure, including area commands, was invested in the newly established Allied Air Forces (AAF) Headquarters under [[South West Pacific Area (command)|South West Pacific Area Command]] (SWPA).Gillison, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070516--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 473]Odgers, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070530--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 15–16] Some finetuning of Western Area's boundaries occurred in August: as well as the Northern Territory, North-Western Area was given responsibility for the portion of Western Australia north of a line drawn south-east from [[Yampi Sound]] to the Northern Territory border.Gillison, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070519--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 588] September 1942 saw the formation of [[RAAF Command]], led by Air Vice Marshal [[William Bostock|Bill Bostock]], to oversee the majority of Australian flying units in the SWPA.Gillison, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070519--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 585–588]Odgers, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070530--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 4–6] Bostock exercised control of air operations through the area commands, although RAAF Headquarters continued to hold overarching administrative authority over all Australian units.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 144–145 In November, construction began on an airfield under Western Area's control at [[Corunna Downs Airfield|Corunna Downs]], near [[Port Hedland, Western Australia|Port Hedland]]. Australia's closest air base to [[Surabaya]], it would serve as a staging post for Allied bombers bound for targets in the [[Dutch East Indies]], allowing them to avoid Japanese fighter stations between [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] and [[Java]].RAAF Historical Section, ''Introduction, Bases, Supporting Organisations'', p. 62Odgers, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070533--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 66] De la Rue handed Western Area over to Air Commodore [[Raymond Brownell]] in December 1942; by the end of the month, headquarters staff numbered 488, including ninety-five officers.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', pp. 302–304Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 187 [[File:SWPA senior officers 1943 (AWM 029236).JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.3|alt=Four men in summer military uniforms in front of a map of northern Australia |Air Commodore Brownell (second from right), Lieutenant-General [[Gordon Bennett (general)|Bennett]] (far right) and Allied naval officers discussing an SWPA situation map, February 1943]] By April 1943, Western Area controlled four combat units: No. 14 Squadron, flying [[Bristol Beaufort]] reconnaissance-bombers out of Pearce; No. 25 Squadron, tasked with [[dive-bomber|dive-bombing]] missions in Wirraways based at Pearce; [[No. 76 Squadron RAAF|No. 76 Squadron]], flying P-40 Kittyhawks out of [[RAAF Learmonth|Potshot]] ([[Exmouth Gulf]]); and [[No. 85 Squadron RAAF|No. 85 Squadron]], operating [[CAC Boomerang]] fighters from Pearce. The area command was also able to call on [[United States Navy|US Navy]] Catalinas of [[Patrol Wing 10]], based at [[Crawley, Western Australia|Crawley]], for reconnaissance and [[Anti-submarine warfare|anti-submarine]] missions.Odgers, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070558--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 140–141] The Beauforts and Catalinas flew several hundred maritime patrols during 1943.Odgers, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070558--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 154] In March 1944, Western Area went on high alert in response to concerns that a Japanese naval force [[Western Australian emergency of March 1944|would raid Western Australia]]. Perth was reinforced with [[No. 452 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 452]] and [[No. 457 Squadron RAAF|457 Squadrons]], and Exmouth Gulf with [[No. 18 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 18]], [[No. 31 Squadron RAAF|31]], and [[No. 120 Squadron RAAF|120 Squadrons]], but no attack ensued and the units were directed to return to their home bases.Odgers, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070557--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 136–139] The US Navy withdrew Patrol Wing 10 mid-year, curtailing Western Area's ability to conduct long-range maritime reconnaissance; No. 14 Squadron's fifteen serviceable Beauforts had to fly patrols of up to twenty-two hours in duration to search for German submarines reported in the area.Odgers, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070395--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 349–350]Stevens, ''A Critical Vulnerability'', pp. 264–265 As of 31 May 1944, Western Area headquarters staff numbered 686, including 118 officers.Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', pp. 359–360 Having converted to [[Vultee Vengeance]] dive bombers in August 1943, No. 25 Squadron moved from Pearce to Cunderdin in January 1945 and re-equipped with [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator|B-24 Liberator]] heavy bombers.Eather, ''Flying Squadrons of the Australian Defence Force'', p. 63 The Liberators were employed on anti-submarine patrol off [[Cape Leeuwin]] later that month, owing to No. 14 Squadron's Beauforts being fully committed to other tasks.Stevens, ''A Critical Vulnerability'', p. 279 Between April and July, No. 25 Squadron provided Western Area's contribution to the [[Borneo campaign (1945)|Borneo campaign]], supporting the Allied [[Battle of Tarakan (1945)|invasions of Tarakan]], [[Battle of North Borneo|Labuan–Brunei]] and [[Battle of Balikpapan (1945)|Balikpapan]].Waters, ''Oboe'', pp. 18, 78, 135 Staging through Corunna Downs, the Liberators bombed Japanese airfields in the Dutch East Indies that were within range of Tarakan, up until the day of the landings on 1 May.Odgers, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070401--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 454–455] They attacked [[Malang]] near Surabaya at night prior to the landings at Labuan, and conducted daylight raids against Java in the lead-up to the Balikpapan operation that commenced on 1 July.Odgers, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070402--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 475–476] No. 14 Squadron had ceased its regular anti-submarine patrols on 23 May following the end of hostilities in Europe, but remained on standby in case any [[U-boat]]s were found to be still active.Odgers, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070395--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 353] In July 1945, Brownell was appointed to command the newly formed [[No. 11 Group RAAF|No. 11 Group]] on [[Morotai]]; he handed Western Area over to his senior air staff officer, Group Captain [[Colin Hannah]], who held temporary command for the remainder of the war.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', pp. 261, 304Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 478 ===Post-war activity and disbandment=== Following the end of the Pacific War in August 1945, SWPA was dissolved and RAAF Headquarters again assumed full control of all its operational formations, including the area commands.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force'', p. 262 Hannah handed over command of Western Area to Group Captain Douglas Wilson in October.Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 496 The RAAF shrank dramatically with demobilisation; wartime units were scheduled for dissolution in several stages, including reconnaissance-bomber squadrons by the end of 1945, and other bomber units by September 1946.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 11–12 No. 14 Squadron was disbanded at Pearce in December 1945.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', p. 45 No. 25 Squadron's Liberators repatriated former prisoners of war from the Dutch East Indies to Australia until January 1946; the unit was disbanded in July that year.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', p. 83 Wilson was placed on the retired list in February 1946, and Hannah again assumed temporary command of Western Area until posted to Britain that October.Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', pp. 523, 531{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46179547 |title=For staff school |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth |date=25 October 1946 |accessdate=18 June 2016 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Group Captain [[Bill Garing]] took over as Officer Commanding Western Area the following month, by which time headquarters staff numbered 117, including thirty-one officers.Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', pp. 587, 593 [[File:Map of Monte Bello Islands - 1952 atomic bomb test (AWM P00131.001).JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.88|Air Commodore Hely coordinated RAAF support for the British atomic test conducted at Montebello, Western Australia, in October 1952|alt=Relief map of Australia, focussing on Western Australia and the Monte Bello Islands]] In September 1946, the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Vice Marshal [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]], proposed reducing the five extant mainland area commands (North-Western, North-Eastern, Eastern, Southern, and Western Areas) to three: Northern Area, covering Queensland and the Northern Territory; Eastern Area, covering New South Wales; and Southern Area, covering Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. The Australian Government rejected the plan and the wartime area command boundaries essentially remained in place.Helson, ''The Private Air Marshal'', pp. 321–325Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 68, 462 No. 25 Squadron re-formed as a Citizen Air Force unit at Pearce in April 1948, operating {{nowrap|[[North American P-51 Mustang|P-51 Mustangs]]}} and, later, [[de Havilland Vampire]] fighters.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', pp. 82–83 As well as training reservists, the squadron was responsible for Western Australia's air defence.Eather, ''Flying Squadrons of the Australian Defence Force'', pp. 63–64 Garing handed over command in November 1948; by the end of the month, Western Area headquarters staff numbered fourteen, including seven officers.Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', pp. 668–670 Group Captain (later Air Commodore) [[William Hely|Bill Hely]] took command of Western Area in October 1951.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48991572 |title=New air chief on citizen training |newspaper=The West Australian |location=Perth |date=24 September 1951 |accessdate=18 June 2016 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49039589 |title=Promotion in RAAF |newspaper=The West Australian |location=Perth |date=2 July 1952 |accessdate=18 June 2016 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} During [[Operation Hurricane]], the British atomic test in the [[Montebello Islands]] in October 1952, Hely coordinated air support including supply and observation flights by [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Dakotas]] of [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 (Transport) Wing]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article65504778 |title=Atomic Weapon Tested |newspaper=[[Benalla Ensign]] |location=Benalla, Victoria |date=27 November 1952 |accessdate=18 June 2016 |page=11 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He completed his term as AOC Western Area in September 1953, by which time headquarters staff numbered thirty-one, including fifteen officers.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18381923 |title=Changes in RAAF commands |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=2 September 1953 |accessdate=18 June 2016 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}Western Area Headquarters, ''Operations Record Book'', p. 774 Commencing the next month, the RAAF was reorganised from a geographically based command-and-control system into one based on function. In February 1954, the newly constituted functional organisations—[[RAAF Air Command|Home]], [[Air Force Training Group RAAF|Training]], and Maintenance Commands—assumed control of all operations, training and maintenance from Western Area Command.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 73–76, 462–463 Western Area remained in existence, but only as one of Home Command's "remote control points".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article23429331 |title=Battle 'nerve-centre' goes north: RAAF fighting control shifted from here |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=21 May 1954 |accessdate=18 June 2016 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The headquarters was finally disbanded on 30 November 1956.{{cite web|url=http://clik.dva.gov.au/history-library/part-3-order-battle/ch-2-order-battle-air-force/s-2-headquarters|title=Order of Battle – Air Force – Headquarters|publisher=[[Department of Veterans' Affairs (Australia)|Department of Veterans' Affairs]]|accessdate=18 June 2016}} ==Order of battle== As at 30 April 1942, Western Area's [[order of battle]] comprised: *RAAF Station Pearce **[[No. 14 Squadron RAAF|No. 14 (General Reconnaissance) Squadron]] **[[No. 25 Squadron RAAF|No. 25 (General Purpose) Squadron]] **[[No. 35 Squadron RAAF|No. 35 (Transport) Squadron]] **[[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|No. 77 (Fighter) Squadron]] *No. 6 Fighter Sector Headquarters, Perth ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite book | year = 2000| title = How Not to Run an Air Force!
